awd_titl_txt: Renewal of REU Site in Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&M University-Commerce
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Texas A&M University - Commerce provides opportunities to eight students from community colleges each summer for ten weeks of research on topics in astrophysics, astronomy, computational physics, engineering physics, optics, material sciences and nuclear physics. In addition to participating in research with an experienced mentor, the REU students will engage in weekly activities to ensure not only that their research stays on track but that they have an engaging collegial and scholarly experience. By the end of the program, every student will have written a research report and presented the results of their work in a talk. 

This REU site will have a number of broader impacts with its focus on providing research opportunities to undergraduates to help prepare them for future science, technology, engineering, and mathematics careers. Additionally, the site focuses on providing research opportunities to students from community colleges and assists them with the transition to a four-year college. The site has put strategies in place to ensure that non-traditional students, many of whom have families, are able to participate in a summer research experience.

por.por_cntn:
This REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) program supported 24 students selected nationally from 2-year community colleges to participate in cutting edge research projects led by faculty members in Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&M University-Commerce. We aimed at establishing a successful model to address the tremendous national need, especially in rural areas, of supporting community college students as they make transitions to 4-year universities to complete their bachelor’s degree in physical science and go on to graduate studies.  Early involvement in research starting from the freshman year has been shown to be one of the most effective ways of attracting talented undergraduates to, and retaining them in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) careers. However, students in 2-year community colleges, especially minority students in the economically underdeveloped areas often do not have the same opportunity to engage in meaningful research as those who begin their postsecondary education in 4-year universities. Community colleges are becoming the primary access point to higher education for those who have been traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields, such as minority, first-generation, nontraditional, and low-income students.

All 24 participants of our REU program have successfully transferred to 4-year colleges and some of them have already entered into top graduate schools. The REU students gained their very first hands-on experience in research and are strongly motivated to become next generation scientists and engineers.
